results.title: Rosalie
results.creator_credit: W S. Van Dyke, William Anthony McGuire and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A rich and lively blend of great songs, great dances, great comedy and plain old period charm, Rosalie is the kind of zany musical they just don’t make anymore. Starring Nelson Eddy as Dick Thorpe, star footballer and West Point cadet and Eleanor Powell as Rosalie, the woman he loves. Cast also includes Frank Morgan, Edna May Oliver, Ray Bolger, Ilona Massey with words and music by Cole Porter. Based on the play by William Anthony McGuire and Guy Bolton. The film is introduced by Bill Collins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W S. Van Dyke, William Anthony McGuire and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer

results.title: Marcel Duchamp: a game of chess
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Drot, RM Associates and INA France
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Filmed in 1963 the program offers an in-depth dialogue between renowned artist Marcel Duchamp and film-maker Jean-Marie Drot over a game of chess and a tour of Duchamp’s first one man show at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1963. Duchamp details his life and work only 5 years before his death in a discussion of his time in the United States after fleeing France in 1915. The discussion touches on his view of the country in social and political terms as well as its impact on his own work, intermingled with visual contemplations on the progression of his artwork from painting to photographs throughout his career. Recognised for varying artistic practices which included brushes with Impressionism and Cubism, Duchamp is also largely known for his founding influence in Surrealism and Dada. Here he recounts the stages of his work with full colour shots of the relevant pieces evoking a detailed sense of the significance of these different times in his life personally, politically and most of all artistically. The game of chess which punctuates the dialogue, a passion for Duchamp throughout his career, acts as an insightful metaphor for the mental discipline he applies to his work and an avenue for its explanation and contemplation. Contains some scenes in b&w. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Rope [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock and Transatlantic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: John Dall and Farley Granger play flat mates (and implied homosexual lovers) who strangle a friend for intellectual thrills and proceed to invite the victim’s family and friends for dinner, believing they have committed the perfect crime. Their former teacher, James Stewart, suspects wrongdoing and by the end of the evening discovers how brutally his students have twisted his own academic theories to justify the murder. Also Stars Sir Cedrick Hardwicke and Constance Collier. Adapted by Hume Cronyn form the play by Patrick Hamilton play that dealt with the Leopold-Loeb murder trial. Screenplay by Arthur Laurents. Cinematography by Joseph Valentine and William V. Skall.

results.title: Donatello 1386-1466: the first modern sculptor
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, RM Arts and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Donatello is said in this documentary to be the most versatile and imaginative of all artists of his century and he is credited with bringing the Renaissance to Italy. The intense and personal work of Donatello is examined here in terms of his vision, emotion and techniques. Most notable is his inventive techniques in his work such as was used in his relief making sculpture. Writer and art historian Charles Avery locates an obscure terra-cotta relief of Donatello’s in Florence and throughout the documentary the authentication of the work is shown. Avery discusses the work of Donatello along with sculptors Henry Moore, Elisabeth Frink, and Peter Rockwell. This documentary was made shortly after the restoration of a number of significant works by Donatello and is the first time that these works can be seen in their former glory revealing a brilliance in colour and detail not seen in recent history.

results.title: Rogopag [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Ugo Tognazzi, Jean-Luc Godard, Pier Pasolini, Roberto Rossellini, Alfredo Bini, Societe Cinematographique Lyre (Paris), Cineruz and Arco Film (Italy)
results.brief_description: This is an anthology of four short comedies. The first episode, Rossellini’s (Ro) farewell to cinema (he worked in television thereafter), is a light-hearted play on the difference between the ‘Anglo-Saxon’ and ‘Latin’ character and the idea of cinematic illusion. The Pasolini (Pa) segment is located on the set of a biblical epic, (Orson Welles is the director) and is full of ideas which Pasolini developed elsewhere in his novels, poetry and films. Godard’s (Go) episode is a kind of science fiction story, foreshadowing Alphaville, set in a Paris transformed but not destroyed by a nuclear bomb. Gregoretti’s (G) piece is distinguished mainly by the presence of the great comic actor Ugo Tognazzi. Contents: Illibatezza Chastity (31 min.) ; Ricotta Curd cheese (b&w, col., 35 min.) ; Nuovo New world (19 min.)—Pollo ruspante Free-range chicken (32 min). Cast includes Rosanna Schiaffino (Illibatezza), Orson Welles (Ricotta), Jean-Marc Bory (Nuovo mondo) and Ugo Gregoretti (Pollo ruspante). In Italian and French with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ugo Tognazzi, Jean-Luc Godard, Pier Pasolini, Roberto Rossellini, Alfredo Bini, Societe Cinematographique Lyre (Paris), Cineruz and Arco Film (Italy)
